Posts.Content: As far as I know I do not have PC, but have had surgery for other things. Now I'm assuming that the prostate is enlarged, thus the catheter is needed. But with your husbands attitude he may as well just keeping on trucking like he is because I do not think he would be the type that would take treatment, even if it meant saving his life. And I'm afraid by now he would need more then surgery or radiation.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kgravy Hey all, sorry to ask this weird question. But, Ive been on the lung cancer forum for a little bit now. Been dealing with that for a little while (and no there has been no confirmation of any kind of cancer yet.) Ill give a quick rundown on some stuff but Ill be somewhat brief. Basically some lung nodules were found, and they grew and biopsy just said suspicious cells. Did a pet scan,those lit up a bit,but my prostate also lit up. I was asked all sorts of questions. I told them about the blood in my urine (have had it for years) my frequent urination, the lymph node in my pubic area thats always swollen, the "dribbling" of urine I always experience. As well as the constant waking up at night to urinate, and weird feeling in my hips, almost achey. Anyways, they did a PSA test (waiting on results) and also did a urine test. Urine test showed high level of blood in urine, as well as no presence of infection or any std. The rectal exam was also done. Said it was enlarged, and possibly some bumpyness to it. She couldnt confirm on the bumpyness but def said it was enlarged for a 26 year old. I mean, its slowly been getting worse for a few years, but I just attested it to anxiety. Now my question, isnt this odd for a 26 year old? I know infections can light up on pet scans as well, and maybe the urine test just cant pick it up. Im just confused as heck right now. Totally derailed my lung dr's current train of thought on what is going on. Now I go back to waiting for some more results and getting a gameplan built. Thanks for listening all, I appreciate it! Reading your thread make me wonder. Will a pet scan show cancer in the prostate with all the body funstions taht are going on there.

Posts.Content: I wish they never invented the PSA test. I know it sounds selfish of me and I'm sure it's help a lot of guys, but for me its been nothing but a nerve racking, anxiety ordeal. My journey started with a physical in Dec 2012 where the PSA was 5.9, up from 2.2. Now 3 years later Ive had two biopsies and many PSA test, my last test number taken this week was 2.8. All the PSA test Ive had have been below 5.9. If I had of just skip that physical in 2012, look at all the trouble free days and weeks I could have spent.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobertG Bowel prep for colonoscopy is pretty much the same as the one you do for prostate biopsy. I've had to do it 4 times now (colonoscopy, prostate biopsy, brachytherapy measurement/seed planning, brachytherapy). You have to go on a clear liquid diet for a day or two. Each time I've had to take Pico-Salax and a lot of water, which results in some jet-powered bowel movements. I hear some docs ask for a Fleet soda enema rather than the Pico-Salax. It's not the most fun couple of days, For the brachy procedure I had to do the Fleet in addition to the Pico-Salax. The colonoscopy procedure itself was cake, I was asleep through it all. Bowel prep for colonoscopy is pretty much the same as the one you do for prostate biopsy. No way. The colonoscopy you drink a gallon jug of crap. The prostate biopsy you just use an enema, and some doctors do not even have you do that.
Posts.Title: Off Topic: Virtual Colonoscopy

Posts.Content: I'm had several Colonoscopy for the past 20 years and they have not come up with anything better today then 20 years ago. There was a time in the early 2000 time frame that you could take pills and drank a lot of water. That was a breeze but since then they stop because they said the pills could cause kidney damage. The last one I had 3 years ago was golightly (spell wrong). It was a gallon jug with a solution in it that you filled with water and you had to drank all of it, nasty. One good thing about the procedure, at least in my hometown, they put you under and that is the best sleep I've ever had. Like others mention what is the plus about doing the virtual if you have to drank the same stuff.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FredM Here's my situation: In 2014 (43 years old), my PCP did a DRE and found a nodule on my prostate. He then did a PSA which was at 0.4, and referred me to a urologist. Urologist wanted to do a biopsy, but we did a 3T MRI instead. MRI showed: - prostate volume = 21 ml - the nodule found from the DRE was likely nothing to worry about - found a lesion in the anterior transitional zone, which was graded a 3 (equivocal) - no sign of high grade cancer, and since PSA is low, urologist suggests doing nothing except testing PSA every 6 months. Since then PSAs have been: - PSA = 0.79 March 2015 - PSA = 0.41 Sept 2015 - PSA = 0.36 March 2016 - PSA = 0.40 Sept 2016 - PSA = 0.23 March 2017 Urologist now says, maybe we should do another MRI since it's been almost 3 years. While I'm not strongly opposed to doing another MRI, I'm wondering if it's really necessary given that PSA has not risen. Any thoughts or advice? Is your decimals in the right place on those PSA numbers. The PSA numbers look like someone without a prostate.

Posts.Content: When I went to my home town urologist July 18th I made up my mind that if my PSA had gotten higher I would have a biopsy. When I met with the doc he said lets go another 6 months and if the PSA is still rising we will do another biopsy. I knew then I wanted to see another urologist because I could not believe he wanted me to go 6 more months. So I had my records sent to Vanderbilt. Met with the urologist there and as we were going over my records he saw the 5.4 PSA and said thats not to bad but then he said wait, did your last biopsy show atypical cells, and I said yes and he wanted to know how long ago was that and I told him over 1 1/2 years and he said you need a biopsy now. That kind of scare me because I could hear the urgency in his voice. So last Thursday I had one at Vanderbilt, 12 core. I asked what about doing a saturation biopsy and he said he only does that when a patient has had more then 2 biopsy and several high PSAs back to back. I thought, well I should be a candidate for that but hes the doctor. Anyway the nurse called this morning and said all 12 cores were negative and did I want her to send the results to my home doc. I said no, I want to stay at Vanderbilt. So without talking to the doctor Im not sure when he will want to do a PSA or another biopsy. All that worry (for now anyway) for nothing. Dec 6, 2011 PSA 2.3 Dec, 11, 2012 PSA 5.9 Jan 2012. saw the urologist who did a DRE and found nothing except enlarged prostate, set up time for biopsy Jan. 22, 2013 had biopsy, results 11 cores negative and one core a few atypical cells April 25, 2013 PSA 3.1 Oct. 29, 2013 3.3 Dec 11, 2013 had a physical from different doctor and PSA was 3.9 Jan 29, 2014 full body CT scan (for a different problem) found Prostatic Hypertrophy April 2, 2014 PSA 4.8, Free PSA 23% July 18, 2014 PSA 5.4 Free PSA 20% Aug 28, 2014 Met with Vanderbilt urologist Oct 2, 2014 Had 2nd biopsy, all cores negative

I can not begin to guess what he might do if the psa is higher than 5.9. Do another biopsy maybe or? I'm 68 years old. I've made up my mind that if another biopsy shows up cancer I will have surgery. Radiation burns your insides out. I live in a small town so if I have it I will go to Vanderbilt. Anyone been treated there.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman PSA has been steadily rising over the last 5 years or so, startingat .7, (age 5, to 3.1 six months ago (age 64 -about to turn 64). The rises have been slow, .7, 1.1, 1.7, 2.1, 2.7, 2.9,2.7, then 3.1 six months ago. Went to uro doc today, got results - 4.3. Seems like a bigger jump than in the past. Also my fPSA was 12. and free to total ratio was 8.6. Had biopsy two year ago, which was negative for PC but showed Hi Grade Pin, in one of 14 cores. So between the large jump, the hi grade pin, and the low free psa, combined with my family history of PC (father), i am pretty much convinced that bad news is on the way. I am scheduled for biopsy next week. UGH. Am i wrong to think the odds of a negative biopsy are very much stacked against me here? My story is kind of like yours. PSA steady going up from 2.1 to 5.9 in 2 years. Had first biopsy about 1 1/2 years ago and he found atypical cells in one core. Had another biopsy this month and all cores were negative. I'm 69. The doc wants to see me in 6 months and not sure what they will do. Did not get to talk to him. He just had his nurse call me and tell me the results and set up a 6 month appointment.

I am scheduled for biopsy next week. UGH. Am i wrong to think the odds of a negative biopsy are very much stacked against me here? My story is kind of like yours. PSA steady going up from 2.1 to 5.9 in 2 years. Had first biopsy about 1 1/2 years ago and he found atypical cells in one core. Had another biopsy this month and all cores were negative. I'm 69. The doc wants to see me in 6 months and not sure what they will do. Did not get to talk to him. He just had his nurse call me and tell me the results and set up a 6 month appointment.

Posts.Content: I've been reading this forum for over a year. I had a PSA of 5.9 and biopsy which was benign except for a few atypical cells in one sample. I'm 69, so I've been going over my options just in case of PC showing up. I have a question; why would someone choose Active Surveillance. Once a person has prostate cancer and let's say he has a low gleason score and then choose's Active Surveillance, what keeps the cancer from spreading during the time between PSA test. I may look at it differently should I come down with PC but to me it makes sense to go ahead and take the treatment. It just seems that while on AS you start having symptoms that it has spread, it would be too late then.

It was just part of my physical that I have every year and I was not even aware of it till it exceeded the normal limits. And then it was just hard to ignore it and not try to find out what's going on.

Posts.Content: Immediate and severe funding cuts may curtail access to cancer clinical trials Statement by ASCO President Clifford A. Hudis, MD, FACP The nations clinical trial network, which provides care to thousands of cancer patients across the United States, may have no choice but to abandon life-saving and life-extending research studies, including support for the patients participating in those studies, due to crippling proposed budget cuts. For decades, federally supported clinical trials have produced critical advances in the fight against cancer, representing one of the greatest returns on research investment anywhere. But this progress could soon grind to a halt due to far-reaching  and largely unnoticedbudgeting decisions that are happening in plain sight. In the face of its own inadequate budget, which Congress should address, the National Cancer Institute has made the decision to end funding for federally-funded clinical trials in the community setting through the Community Clinical Oncology Program (CCOP). As of June 1, 2014, support for the CCOP program will end, jeopardizing care for thousands of patients in communities across the United Statesunless and until these research programs receive new NCI research grant funding that is not available until at least September 2014. This will result in a dangerous disruption of cancer care for patients who rely on these trials. The CCOPs are 60-plus community-based cancer research programs that make participation in clinical trials possible in nearly every community across America. To be very clear, they are being forced to choose between either ceasing research activities or self-funding it. At the same time, the new National Clinical Trials Network, which replaced the nations previous Cooperative Group clinical trials system, faces a 40 percent reduction in operating budgets. This is forcing NCTN leaders to make an unreasonable choice: either halt critical research studies currently underwayand in the process renege on obligations to patients committed to these studiesor cancel planned and urgently needed new trials. Either choice spells the end or a significant slowing of research that could have delivered new treatments and more personalized and effective care to millions of Americans with cancer. These budget decisions mean that progress will slow. Life-saving therapies will be significantly delayed or not studied at all, local access to state-of-the-art treatments will be reduced, and patients currently receiving study treatments may no longer have expenses reimbursed or could even see their therapy interrupted. At a time when there are enormous and unprecedented opportunities to improve cancer care, America shouldnt be turning its back on cancer patients and science. Federally-funded trials have produced some of the biggest advances in cancer care, saving and improving countless lives over the last 50 years. We should not put cancer patients and our scientific leadership in jeopardy by interrupting funding for community-based cancer research. We urge NCI to restore budgets to NCTN operations to prevent the gap in funding to community-based centers that will cause this otherwise avoidable damage to our research infrastructure and progress while ensuring that patients with cancer receive critically important, life-extending care, regardless of where they live
Posts.Title: Cancer patients face treatment disruptions come June,

Posts.Content: I've been reading this forum for over a year and right now I'm very nervous. I'll be 69 in June and you can read my stats below. The reason I'm nervous is, for the past 4 or 5 months I've been having a nagging pain in my lower back off and on and also the right hip. Of course my first thought was PC in the bones even though I do not know yet if I have PC. Last time I saw the urologist was 5 1/2 months ago. I went there today to give a blood sample and will see him next week for results. I was suppose to see him at the end of April but managed to get it moved up. When I went by there last month to see him sooner they asked why and I told them about the back pain. The lady at the desk said we do not treat back pain you need to see an orthopaedic doctor. After explaining to her my concern she still said no and then I just said, well, it burns every time I pee. She said OK, we will move your appointment up. So what do you guys think. The way my PSA is going up, could I have prostate cancer and could it be advanced enough to be in the bones. I did have a full body CT scan on an unrelated problem 2 months ago and the report said prostatic hypertrophy, which I believe means enlarged prostate, which I knew I had for several years. I think regardless of the PSA he will want to do another biopsy or bone scan or? Dec 6, 2011 PSA 2.3 Dec, 11, 2012 PSA 5.9 Jan 2013. saw the uroligist who did a DRE and found nothing except enlarged prostate, set up time for biopsy Jan. 22, 2013 had biopsy, results 11 cores negative and one core a few atypical cells. Only one lab saw the slides. April 25, 2013 PSA 3.1 Oct. 29, 2013 3.3 Dec 11, 2013 had a physical from different doctor and PSA was 3.9 Jan 29, 2014 full body CT scan, found Prostatic Hypertrophy April 2, 2014 PSA?, will know results in one week.

Posts.Content: I've been to two urologist and never has any of them told me to stop sex, bicycle, running, etc before a PSA test. Or they just not concern with the test results or do they not believe these activities will effect the PSA test. The last PSA test, the dr wanted to do the finger exam before the blood test. I said it may effect the results and could he do it after the exam. He said they do not believe in that myth anymore. He did as I asked anyway but I could tell he was a little taken back by my request.

You would think once you had cancer you could go to the back of the line and not have another type, but that's just not the way life is.

Posts.Content: I've been watching my PSA for 7 years. The highest it has been was 5.9. It had been in the low 2's. Had 2 biopsy, the first one (Jan 2013) had atypical cells in one of the cores. The second biopsy(Oct 2014) found nothing. Since then have had several PSA done with my family doctor and the urologist. PSA jumps around some but never over 5.9 and mostly in the 4 range. My urologist at Vanderbilt, who I see once a year, called and said recent PSA is 4.2 and FREE PSA 47%. I said the free number sounds pretty good to me, what does it mean to you. Doctor said based on my age (73) and PSA numbers, I have a 12% change of getting prostate cancer. She tried to explain the math involved in coming up with that number but I could not follow. I guess I'm OK for now but those atypical cells still concern me.

AgeInfo.Phrase: said based on my age  73  and PSA numbers  I have

Posts.Title: 12% chance of getting prostate cancer

Posts.Content: I would do the biopsy. It's the easiest procedure you will ever have. The doctor felt something so he was concerned. Hunting for a doctor that will tell you what you want to hear could mean losing precious time. Right now it's on your mind and will probably be on your mind next week and so on. At least with a biopsy you will either be able to forget it or fight it.

Sorry but you guys will not hear any of my very thoughtful answers and posts.

Posts.Content: You guys probably already know about these drugs but there was an article in the today's paper written by an oncologist doctor who stated that Zytiga and Xtaudt have been approved foe people who have become resistant to hormone treatment instead of having to start chemotheraphy. These drugs are designed to inhibit the production of androgen in the testes, adrental glands and prostate tumors themselves.
Posts.Title: Zytiga and Xtaudi

Posts.Content: I know this question has been asked thousand times but are any of you taking a supplement that you think is helping with your prostate. Like saw palmetto, etc. Now if you do a search you will find a thread where I was taking a pomegranate pill but later read that that could rise the PSA number so I stopped. Now, I have not been diagnosed with PC yet but I probably have it based on a biopsy that I had which found atypical cell and a PSA of 5.9. I will be 74 in June. So are there any magic pills out there. Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mikla Good question. It's been awhile since I've read up on it but I seem to remember saturation biopsies can be don first when an imaging technique or DRE may have indicated an increased chance of cancer (and location). It seems logical that after one biopsy, a second one can be more targeted based on the results of the first. Typical number of cores I have seen range from 20 to 40. Forgive me if you've posted this elsewhere, but what was the result of your last biopsy? All 12 cores were benign. Since the nurse called me with the results I did not get a chance to talk to the doctor to see what happens if PSA keeps going up. I have an appointment in 6 months. I had this one, my second biopsy, at Vanderbilt thinking maybe they would have more experience in giving a biopsy. The only difference I noticed, comparing the first one with this one, was on a few cores he took, it felt like he was really pushing hard on that spring loaded gizmo they use. Maybe to get more tissue, not sure.
